itemDescription: British Conservative Party politician and author (born 1966)

wikipedia_page.main: Tobias Martin Ellwood  (born 12 August 1966) is a British Conservative Party politician, soldier and author. He served in the Royal Green Jackets and reached the rank of captain. He currently serves as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Bournemouth East, and served as a UK Government Minister at the Ministry of Defence from 2017 to 2019.

response: *1966 – Tobias Ellwood, American-English captain and politician

Bournemouth is represented by two parliamentary constituencies in the House of Commons; Bournemouth East and Bournemouth West. In the 2017 general election, the former was held for the Conservatives by Tobias Ellwood with 51.9% of the vote, while the latter was also held for the Conservatives by Conor Burns with 53.5%. However, the seats saw some of the largest increases in Labour vote share in the country, with increases of over 18% in each.
File:Official portrait of Mr Tobias Ellwood crop 2.jpg|Tobias Ellwood, Conservative MP

On 28 February 2019, after a revision of the Defence Estates Optimisation Plan, MoD minister Tobias Ellwood MP announced that RAF Halton would not close until at least 2025. This was confirmed in letters sent from the Defence Infrastructure Organisation in May 2019 to local residents, stating that phased withdrawal would commence in 2022 with full disposal achieved in 2025.

response: As of 2020, there are three Conservative Members of the House of Commons that are UK-USA dual nationals; Greg Hands, Tobias Ellwood and Joy Morrissey.
